title: How to Stop Getting Distracted by Your Phone when Studying

steps.title: Switch on the “Do Not Disturb” mode.
steps.content: Switch on the “Do Not Disturb” mode. iPhone and Android phones have settings that allow you to mute all notification beeps and calls during a time of your choosing. When you want to study, you should use your quick settings to turn this mode on, and don’t return to it until you have completed your study session. On iPhones, swipe up from the home screen to access your basic settings. Tap the moon shape and this function will be enabled. On Android phones, pull down the notifications drawer. Swipe down again to access the quick settings. Turn the Do not disturb function and select the amount of time you want it to be active. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Download a timing app or use your timer to work for a period of time.
steps.content: Download a timing app or use your timer to work for a period of time. After you have turned on your “Do Not Disturb” mode, set your timer for 30 minutes and place it far away from you. When the timer beeps, stop working and take a five to 10 minute break. You can download an app called Pomodoro or Unplugged that set timers for you and tracks your progress. With some of these apps, they remind you to set the phone down if you try to use it during the allotted time.

steps.title: Use Airplane mode to turn off your ability to connect to an outside network.
steps.content: Use Airplane mode to turn off your ability to connect to an outside network. Also, turn off Wi-Fi. This will stop calls and texts from coming through, and it will not allow you to access distracting apps.

steps.title: Inform your friends that you are unavailable when you are studying.
steps.content: Inform your friends that you are unavailable when you are studying. Block out regular time when they know you will be unavailable.

steps.title: Place your phone on a shelf or in another area of the room, rather than on your desk.
steps.content: Place your phone on a shelf or in another area of the room, rather than on your desk.

steps.title: Give your phone to a friend, if you can’t stay away from it.
steps.content: Give your phone to a friend, if you can’t stay away from it. A physical barrier may make you feel ashamed that you can’t do without your phone. Make yourself accountable to someone.

steps.title: Make a to-do list so that you have a feasible game plan for your study session.
steps.content: Make a to-do list so that you have a feasible game plan for your study session. It will help you map out the process, and crossing things off your list as you do them will give you a lot of pleasure.

steps.title: Create blocks of tasks.
steps.content: Create blocks of tasks. Make sure these tasks are no more than 25 to 30 minutes. This is the amount of time you can expect yourself to focus without any disruptions. [2] X Research source Splitting your studying into separate tasks can also ensure you do a thorough job. For example, you may have a research session, an outlining session and a session where you write each of the major points in a paper.

steps.title: Do the most important/hardest tasks near the beginning of your study session.
steps.content: Do the most important/hardest tasks near the beginning of your study session. You may want to get one or two easier tasks done right away in order to feel like you’ve accomplished something, but then you should try to take care of the highest priorities while you are more focused. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Get up and move around after you have completed a task block.
steps.content: Get up and move around after you have completed a task block. Try to clear your head by getting something to eat or going outside.

steps.title: Time yourself when you use your phone during a break.
steps.content: Time yourself when you use your phone during a break. Set your timer for five minutes so that you only take care of the most important things.

steps.title: Pay attention to the things that help you “flow.
steps.content: Pay attention to the things that help you “flow. ” This is the feeling of being lost in a task enough to ignore time and simply do the task. Note the times when this happens and try to recreate the environment.

steps.title: Work into longer periods of flow.
steps.content: Work into longer periods of flow. After doing 25-minute blocks, you may be able to move to 60-minute blocks, where you are able to get larger tasks done.
